BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 12, 1923

VOL. XXVIII, No. 3

CAPTAIN BOOTH ADDRESSES HOPKINS TO PLACE QUINTET HOPKINS Y. M. C. A. CAMPAIGN FOR MEMBERS
ON COURUT
TRACK MEN AT ORGANISTARTED WEDNESDAY
ZATION MEETING
Practice to Be Held at Armory. Ash1923-24 Track Prospects Brightest in
Years

Captain Booth asserted at the
meeting of track men, at which
over forty new candidates as well
as many of last year's stars were
present, that Hopkins track athletics are in for a year of triumph.
Both Captain Booth and Manager
Geib are highly elated over the
large attendance which contained
many men who were stars on their
prep school teams—cinder track
artists as well as field event men.
Among the veterans who are returning are: Clarke, star sprinter
and uncrowned king of the 9 3-5
second men; Hambleton, weights
leader; Proctor, high jumper; Dorcus, of the 440; Norwood and Wasson, the cross country harriers.
Last but far from being least is
Captain Booth, the lengthy miler,
Who led the pack to the finish in
many a gruelling run of last year.
Captain Booth gave the men a
short talk on conditioning. He
stressed the point that regularity
more than anything else was the
high factor of condition. "Let a
man be regular in meals, sleep and
training and the way to success in
track work lies open," was one of
the pithy sentences of the captain's
speech.
Initial practice will be called for
Tuesday afternoon at 4 o'clock at
the field. Every man is expected to
be on hand to report to Captain
Booth and Assistant Clarke for the
Sprints, and Hambleton for the
Weight events. Old men are asked
to turn in their equipment and it is
assured that all new men will be
Candidates
completely outfitted.
for all events are well divided, although sprints men seem to predominate. A strong, well-balanced
squad certainly will provide the nucleus for another prize winning aggregation if early deductions may
be drawn.
DEBATING COUNCIL TO
ORGANIZE
The Debating Council will hold
a meeting in the near future to
elect a secretary and to discuss
the present year's program. As
in former years in addition to the
Varsity debates there will be several inter-class debates. There
will be, after custom, a Freshman-Sophomore debate and the
twenty-seventh annual Adams
Debate between the Juniors and
drawal from school of August Levene, '25. This year's program is
Seniors.
The Varsity team will be in the
Annual Triangular Debate with
Washington and Lee and the
University of North Carolina and
Will probably have an entrant in
expected to be both bigger and
the Southern Oratorical Contest
In addition to the regular intercollegiate schedule.
This year the President of the
Debating Council is j. Edward
Mount, '24, and the position of
Secretary-Treasurer is left open
by the withdrawal from school
of August Levene, '25. This
Year's program is expected to
be both bigger and better
than last year's highly successful
schedule which was so far advanced over anything ever attempted in preceding years.

ton to Manage Squad

After an absence of two seasons
Johns Hopkins will again be represented on the basketball court.
With the election of Ashton as
manager at the last meeting of the
A. A. Board the plans for this season got under way.
A large squad is expected to answer the first call for candidates,
which will be about the first of December. Martin is the only veteran of the last Black and Blue team
who will be eligible for this year's
five. Dorsey, an engineering senior,
is one of the many undergraduates
with a fine record in scholastic circles. Others are Conner, former
City College star; Townsend, an
old Poly man; Berndt, of Friends,
and Day, from Central High of
Washington. Carl Wilson is reported as leading a likely contingent from the Medical School.
Games are being arranged now
and Manager Ashton is communicating with St. John's, Maryland,
Loyola, Western Maryland, Gallaudet, Mt. St. Mary's, George
Washington, and Navy. The last
two will be met away, but the other
teams will be played under contracts calling for two games, one
at home, the other away.
Practice and home games will be
held at the Fifth Regiment Armory.
Present plans call for games during January and February on Saturday nights. There will be dancing after each contest.

MT. ST. MARY'S TO MEET
HOPKINS
Continued from page 1

Princeton was lucky to win. When
the safety which the team earned
but which the referees would not
allow, the attempt by Turnbull at
a field goal which missed by
inches, and the recovery of a fumble by Maxwell with a clear field
ahead of him, only to have a
Princeton man clutch his jersey
from the rear long enough to
check him, are considered; we are
easily understand how lucky
Princeton was to win.
This week Coaches Van Orman
and O'Rourke have been sending
the men through long signal drills
and occasional short scrimmages.
Fundamentals have been continuously stressed and the squad is
in excellent shape. The casualty
list has almost entirely disappeared. Walker Taylor, out of last
week's game due to an injury, may
be seen in action this week. Cook's
injured foot is giving him no further trouble.
What will probably prove of
great advantage to the team this
season and what was only moderately good last year, is the allaround kicking of Turnbull. He
easily out-punted Van Gerbig of
Princeton in last week's struggle.
His kicking off was good and his
place-kicking is reliable as was
proved in the St. John's game of
last season. Turnbull has, greatly
improved in the kicking department since last season. His long
punts were largely responsible
for Princeton's low score last
week.
The Hopkins line, although
light, has great defensive ability.
Princeton
could
gain
little
through the line and resorted
mostly to an aerial attack. In the
last two minutes of last week's
encounter, with their goal line
threatened, the Black and Blue
line held their ground like a stone
wall. The back field had little opportunity to show any offense last
Saturday. What they can do in
this respect will be seen tomorrow.

If your burning ambition is to excel as an all-

around society man, you couldn't have planned
your evenings better. Such. persistence will win
out over the indolence of the rank and file, for as
the poet says,
'The heights by great men reached and kept
Were not attained by sudden flight,
But they while their compar;ons slept
Were toiling upward ip the night."
But if yeti intend to make your mark in engineering or business, don't expect that supremacy
on the waxed floor will help when you start huntLing a job.
Not that you need swing to the other extreme
as a "grind" or a hermit. Let's concede it is all
right to minor in sociabilities—but certainly it is
only common sense to major in the math and
sciences and English that will mean bread and
butter to you later on.
Remember this—the harder you work right
now in getting a grip on fundamentals, the easier
things will come to you when you must solve
still bigger problems. And if you take it easy
now—well,look out for the law of compensation.
It's up to you. While you've got the chance,
seize it, dig in, plug hard. It will pay—in
cold cash.

All letters intended for publication

Main Part of Meeting

The Junior Class held its initial
meeting on •Tuesday in the Civil
Engineering Hall. Last year's unfinished business was attended to
before the retiring president, Daniel C. Klein, called for nominations
for new officers.
"Ben" Thomas, captaini of baseball, addressed the class in regard
to interclass baseball and urged all
possible candidates to report to him
on Thursday to prepare for the
opening contest of Juniors vs.
Freshmen. All equipment with the
exception of gloves will be furnished the candidates.
Kelso Morrell, chairman of the
ring committee, announced that
Bailey, Banks and Biddle, jewelry
firm, were to furnish new designs
for a Hopkins ring which would
be sold for $15.00.
Nominations for officers are as
follows: President—Reese, Donaldson, Howard, Parsons, Magill.
Vice-President — Tilghman, Asendorf, Donaldson, Griffith.
Secretary — M. Skinner, Conning, Calhoun, Donaldson, Wienfeld.
Treasurer — Summers, Conning,

SCHEDULE REVISED
The Fall Baseball Interclass
Schedule is now in full swing. The
schedule has been changed somewhat in order that all games might
be played before the weather becomes too cold. In all there will
be six games, each class team
meeting each other class. The team
receiving the highest average for
the six games will be declared the
winner.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 12, 1923

VOL. XXVIII, No. 3

CAPTAIN BOOTH ADDRESSES HOPKINS TO PLACE QUINTET HOPKINS Y. M. C. A. CAMPAIGN FOR MEMBERS
ON COURUT
TRACK MEN AT ORGANISTARTED WEDNESDAY
ZATION MEETING
Practice to Be Held at Armory. Ash1923-24 Track Prospects Brightest in
Years

Captain Booth asserted at the
meeting of track men, at which
over forty new candidates as well
as many of last year's stars were
present, that Hopkins track athletics are in for a year of triumph.
Both Captain Booth and Manager
Geib are highly elated over the
large attendance which contained
many men who were stars on their
prep school teams—cinder track
artists as well as field event men.
Among the veterans who are returning are: Clarke, star sprinter
and uncrowned king of the 9 3-5
second men; Hambleton, weights
leader; Proctor, high jumper; Dorcus, of the 440; Norwood and Wasson, the cross country harriers.
Last but far from being least is
Captain Booth, the lengthy miler,
Who led the pack to the finish in
many a gruelling run of last year.
Captain Booth gave the men a
short talk on conditioning. He
stressed the point that regularity
more than anything else was the
high factor of condition. "Let a
man be regular in meals, sleep and
training and the way to success in
track work lies open," was one of
the pithy sentences of the captain's
speech.
Initial practice will be called for
Tuesday afternoon at 4 o'clock at
the field. Every man is expected to
be on hand to report to Captain
Booth and Assistant Clarke for the
Sprints, and Hambleton for the
Weight events. Old men are asked
to turn in their equipment and it is
assured that all new men will be
Candidates
completely outfitted.
for all events are well divided, although sprints men seem to predominate. A strong, well-balanced
squad certainly will provide the nucleus for another prize winning aggregation if early deductions may
be drawn.
DEBATING COUNCIL TO
ORGANIZE
The Debating Council will hold
a meeting in the near future to
elect a secretary and to discuss
the present year's program. As
in former years in addition to the
Varsity debates there will be several inter-class debates. There
will be, after custom, a Freshman-Sophomore debate and the
twenty-seventh annual Adams
Debate between the Juniors and
drawal from school of August Levene, '25. This year's program is
Seniors.
The Varsity team will be in the
Annual Triangular Debate with
Washington and Lee and the
University of North Carolina and
Will probably have an entrant in
expected to be both bigger and
the Southern Oratorical Contest
In addition to the regular intercollegiate schedule.
This year the President of the
Debating Council is j. Edward
Mount, '24, and the position of
Secretary-Treasurer is left open
by the withdrawal from school
of August Levene, '25. This
Year's program is expected to
be both bigger and better
than last year's highly successful
schedule which was so far advanced over anything ever attempted in preceding years.

ton to Manage Squad

After an absence of two seasons
Johns Hopkins will again be represented on the basketball court.
With the election of Ashton as
manager at the last meeting of the
A. A. Board the plans for this season got under way.
A large squad is expected to answer the first call for candidates,
which will be about the first of December. Martin is the only veteran of the last Black and Blue team
who will be eligible for this year's
five. Dorsey, an engineering senior,
is one of the many undergraduates
with a fine record in scholastic circles. Others are Conner, former
City College star; Townsend, an
old Poly man; Berndt, of Friends,
and Day, from Central High of
Washington. Carl Wilson is reported as leading a likely contingent from the Medical School.
Games are being arranged now
and Manager Ashton is communicating with St. John's, Maryland,
Loyola, Western Maryland, Gallaudet, Mt. St. Mary's, George
Washington, and Navy. The last
two will be met away, but the other
teams will be played under contracts calling for two games, one
at home, the other away.
Practice and home games will be
held at the Fifth Regiment Armory.
Present plans call for games during January and February on Saturday nights. There will be dancing after each contest.

HOPKINS
Continued from page 1

Princeton was lucky to win. When
the safety which the team earned
but which the referees would not
allow, the attempt by Turnbull at
a field goal which missed by
inches, and the recovery of a fumble by Maxwell with a clear field
ahead of him, only to have a
Princeton man clutch his jersey
from the rear long enough to
check him, are considered; we are
easily understand how lucky
Princeton was to win.
This week Coaches Van Orman
and O'Rourke have been sending
the men through long signal drills
and occasional short scrimmages.
Fundamentals have been continuously stressed and the squad is
in excellent shape. The casualty
list has almost entirely disappeared. Walker Taylor, out of last
week's game due to an injury, may
be seen in action this week. Cook's
injured foot is giving him no further trouble.
What will probably prove of
great advantage to the team this
season and what was only moderately good last year, is the allaround kicking of Turnbull. He
easily out-punted Van Gerbig of
Princeton in last week's struggle.
His kicking off was good and his
place-kicking is reliable as was
proved in the St. John's game of
last season. Turnbull has, greatly
improved in the kicking department since last season. His long
punts were largely responsible
for Princeton's low score last
week.
The Hopkins line, although
light, has great defensive ability.
Princeton
could
gain
little
through the line and resorted
mostly to an aerial attack. In the
last two minutes of last week's
encounter, with their goal line
threatened, the Black and Blue
line held their ground like a stone
wall. The back field had little opportunity to show any offense last
Saturday. What they can do in
this respect will be seen tomorrow.

If your burning ambition is to excel as an all-

around society man, you couldn't have planned
your evenings better. Such. persistence will win
out over the indolence of the rank and file, for as
the poet says,
'The heights by great men reached and kept
Were not attained by sudden flight,
But they while their compar;ons slept
Were toiling upward ip the night."
But if yeti intend to make your mark in engineering or business, don't expect that supremacy
on the waxed floor will help when you start huntLing a job.
Not that you need swing to the other extreme
as a "grind" or a hermit. Let's concede it is all
right to minor in sociabilities—but certainly it is
only common sense to major in the math and
sciences and English that will mean bread and
butter to you later on.
Remember this—the harder you work right
now in getting a grip on fundamentals, the easier
things will come to you when you must solve
still bigger problems. And if you take it easy
now—well,look out for the law of compensation.
It's up to you. While you've got the chance,
seize it, dig in, plug hard. It will pay—in
cold cash.

All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an' indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

Main Part of Meeting

The Junior Class held its initial
meeting on •Tuesday in the Civil
Engineering Hall. Last year's unfinished business was attended to
before the retiring president, Daniel C. Klein, called for nominations
for new officers.
"Ben" Thomas, captaini of baseball, addressed the class in regard
to interclass baseball and urged all
possible candidates to report to him
on Thursday to prepare for the
opening contest of Juniors vs.
Freshmen. All equipment with the
exception of gloves will be furnished the candidates.
Kelso Morrell, chairman of the
ring committee, announced that
Bailey, Banks and Biddle, jewelry
firm, were to furnish new designs
for a Hopkins ring which would
be sold for $15.00.
Nominations for officers are as
follows: President—Reese, Donaldson, Howard, Parsons, Magill.
Vice-President — Tilghman, Asendorf, Donaldson, Griffith.
Secretary — M. Skinner, Conning, Calhoun, Donaldson, Wienfeld.
Treasurer — Summers, Conning,

INTERCLASS BASEBALL
SCHEDULE REVISED
The Fall Baseball Interclass
Schedule is now in full swing. The
schedule has been changed somewhat in order that all games might
be played before the weather becomes too cold. In all there will
be six games, each class team
meeting each other class. The team
receiving the highest average for
the six games will be declared the
winner.
